name: Coconut Chutney
history: Coconut Chutney is a staple in South Indian cuisine, traditionally served with dishes like dosa, idli, and vada. Its creamy texture and rich flavor come from the primary ingredient, fresh coconut, which is a key element in South Indian cooking.
description: Coconut Chutney is a creamy, flavorful condiment made from fresh grated coconut, green chilies, and various seasonings. It's typically blended with water and tempered with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and dried red chilies for added flavor.

instructions.title: Blend the Chutney
instructions.description: In a blender, combine the grated coconut, green chilies, ginger, roasted chana dal, tamarind paste, salt, and water. Blend until smooth.

instructions.title: Prepare the Tempering
instructions.description: Heat oil in a small pan. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add dried red chilies and curry leaves. Fry for a few seconds.

instructions.title: Temper the Chutney
instructions.description: Pour the tempering over the blended chutney and mix well.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the coconut chutney with idli, dosa, or other South Indian dishes.

tips: Adjust the amount of green chilies to control the spice level.
The chutney can be made thicker or thinner by adjusting the amount of water.
variations: Add mint leaves or coriander leaves for a different flavor.
For a sweeter version, add a little jaggery or sugar.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

presentationTips: Serve in a small traditional Indian bowl or dip container.
Garnish with a sprig of curry leaves for a fresh, appealing look.
